awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nonlinear Solid-State Thermal to Electrical Power Generators
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract 
Nontechnical: 
Solid-state thermal-to-electrical conversion devices such as thermoelectric, thermionic and Nernst power generators are proposed for industrial waste heat recovery and solar-thermal-electrical conversion modules. They provide a clean, noise-free, reliable and green energy solution. Most of these devices are of low efficiency, which limits their applications in the market. They are mostly studied and designed to operate in the linear regime under small temperature differences. Like any other heat engine, the efficiency increases as the temperature difference increases. Therefore, in real applications, it is desired to impose large temperature differences to obtain higher output powers and higher efficiencies. When large temperature differences are applied, electrons are out of equilibrium with lattice and under highly non-equilibrium conditions, responses can be nonlinear. Here, the PI will study the highly non-equilibrium and nonlinear regime numerically using a comprehensive Monte Carlo method for electron transport. The PI will use thermo-reflectance technique to study the device operation experimentally. The experimental and numerical results will be used to design solid-state power generators suitable to work under large temperature differences. The results serve as a step toward wide commercialization of solid-state power generators. The PI will partner with different local programs to arrange for workshops throughout the year, in which the PI will design different hands-on activities and will introduce students to computer programing, thermal imaging, and renewable energies.  
Technical: 
In solid-state power generators, it is desired to transport heat from cathode to anode via electrons while restricting heat transport via lattice. Therefore, it is advantageous to have highly non-equilibrium electrons and operate in the nonlinear regime. Most theoretical tools developed so far are valid only in the linear transport regime where the output powers are small. In the linear transport, materials figure of merit, ZT, determines the efficiency. In the nonlinear regime, ZT is not the only relevant parameter and other parameters such as convective heat transfer coefficient, strength of electron-phonon coupling; applied field and geometry of the device play important roles. To study the nonlinear regime, the PI will develop a Monte Carlo code for electron-phonon transport, enabling investigation of charge, spin and heat transport under large applied fields and for different device geometries. The inputs of the code including interfacial transmission will be calculated using first principles. In addition to the capability of this tool, such numerical codes will help developing a fundamental understanding of transport and insights for developing analytical models for device analysis. The full solution of heat transfer problem including convection/radiation will address more practical but equally important aspect of the efficiency optimization problem. Finally, the PI will use thermo-reflectance imaging and thermomagnetic characterization to study nonlinear transport experimentally. These experiments provide a method for validation of the numerical predictions and additional insights to the device operation.

por.por_cntn:
Solid-state devices enabling thermal to electrical power generation and heat management are essential and should be an integrated part of the energy sector to improve the efficiency of the grid, and power the wearables and the space shuttles. Within this proposal, we developed measurement tools to characterize materials transport properties that determine the thermal-to-electrical energy conversion efficiency, including thermal, electrical, thermoelectric, thermionic, and thermomagnetic properties. These techniques were successfully used to measure the thermoelectric and thermomagnetic properties of single crystals and thin films, the in-plane thermal conductivity of supported thin films, and cross-plane thermionic transport in 2D layered stacks.

On the theoretical/computational side, we have developed, tested, and validated fitting-free, first-principles-based methodologies to either integrate the existing codes (in the case of thermoelectrics) or develop new complementary codes/modules (in the case of thermionic and thermomagnetics) to replicate the experimental results and to optimize a given material transport properties computationally. This prevents the need for synthesis and characterization of many samples for optimization and allows a computationally guided and efficient approach to finding high-performance materials.

Many 2D layered materials, semimetals, and weak metals were studied experimentally and theoretically within this proposal. Semimetals and surface-doped hybrid organic-inorganic materials were investigated as less explored classes of thermoelectric materials. 2D Van der Waals Heterostructures were studied as solid-state thermionic structures. Finally, topological semimetals were studied as potentially good thermomagnetic materials. New applications were proposed and demonstrated in the case of thermoelectric modules. Active cooling or active heat sink where active and passive heat currents are combined to maximize heat transfer, were introduced and demonstrated in metallic thermoelectric materials. Modules made out of cobalt and CePd3 demonstrated that the thermal conductivity can increase from 50 to 1000 W/mK. Thermal switching is proposed and demonstrated in which thermoelectric current can be used to switch between a thermal insulator and a thermal conductor.

Seven Ph.D. students were partially funded at various stages of their Ph. D. from this funding and 4 of them already graduated and received their degrees. Four undergraduate students had the opportunity to do research with the group on this proposal. Two book chapters and 17 Journal papers were published and the results were presented in more than 30 conference oral and poster presentations including 17 invited talks.

The group has served the community throughout the funding period. Workshops, science demos, and after-school programs were conducted at local preschools, elementary schools, and nonprofit organizations.
